trial_identification.studytitle: Evaluation of six-minute walk distance and average speed in subjects with lung disorders.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Evaluation of six-minute walk distance and average speed in subjects with lung disorders

interventions.interventions: The patients have been perform the Six-minute walk test according to American Thoracic Society. The test was performed only once
interventions.comparator: The patients were divided in three groups obstructive, restrictive and mixed from the lung functions results. And after compare the six-minute walk distance and average speed between the groups.

primaryOutcome.timepoint: at after performed the six-minute walk test

primaryOutcome.outcome: Average speed in six-minute walk test

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Patients witih diagnosis of lung disorders.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Healthy subjects, patients with needed supplemental oxygen , and subjects with cardiovascular and neurological disorders

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The six-minute walking test (6MWT) is a submaximal clinic assessment tool, which has produced good results when employed in subjects with lung disease, diagnosticated as from a lung function test. However, the objectives of this studyare evaluate and compare the six-minute walking distance (6MWD) with predicted six-minute walking distance in different lung disorders; as well as the average speed during the 6MWT. Beyond to check if age, body-mass index, lung function and average speed can influence the 6MWT response. In this study was included 124 subjects with lung diseases, which have been divided in three groups: obstructive, restrictive and mixed from the lung functions results. Have been evaluated their anthropometrics and personal data, and then sent to perform the 6MWT according to ATS.
